conclusion: Analyze the motion of charged particles in the velocity selector to find kinetic energy of the second particle.
For a particle to pass through the velocity selector without deviation, electric force and magnetic force must balance each other.
Electric force is given by F_e = qE.
Magnetic force is given by F_m = qvB.
For the particle to pass through without deviation, qE = qvB implies E = vB.
First particle with mass m and charge q passes through the velocity selector with velocity v.
From the balance condition, v = E/B.
Second particle has mass 2m and charge q, deviates by distance d from the dashed line when it leaves N.
Deviation d is due to imbalance between electric and magnetic forces.
Net force on the second particle is F_net = qE - qv'B.
Net force causes deviation d over length L of the velocity selector.
Acceleration a due to net force is a = (qE - qv'B)/(2m).
Deviation d can be related to acceleration and length L: d = (1/2) a t^2.
Time t to travel length L is t = L/v'.
Substituting t into deviation equation: d = (1/2) ((qE - qv'B)/(2m)) (L/v')^2.
Using E = vB from the first particle.
Simplifying: d = (1/2) ((qvB - qv'B)/(2m)) (L/v')^2.
Rearranging to solve for v': v' = qBL^2/(4md).
Calculate kinetic energy E_k of the second particle.
Kinetic energy E_k = (1/2) (2m) v'^2.
Substituting v': E_k = (1/2) (2m) (qBL^2/(4md))^2.
